title: Present perfect simple and continuous
introduction: Do you know the difference between We've painted the room and We've been painting the room? Test what you know with interactive exercises and read the explanation to help you.
explanation: We use both the present perfect simple (have or has + past participle) and the present perfect continuous (have or has + been + -ing form) to talk about past actions or states which are still connected to the present.
keyPoints: we can see evidence of recent activity
examples: Do you know the difference between We've painted the room and We've been painting the room?
Look at these examples to see how the present perfect simple and continuous are used.
I've had three coffees already today!
She's read ten books this summer.
When we can see evidence of recent activity
How long have you known each other?
We've known each other since we were at school.
How long have they been playing tennis?
They've been playing tennis for an hour.
They've been playing tennis every Sunday for years.
Sometimes the present perfect continuous can emphasise that a situation is temporary.
